noun.description: The visible shape or configuration of something.
examples: the form, color, and texture of the tree

noun.description: A particular way in which a thing exists or appears; a manifestation.
examples: her obsession has taken the form of compulsive exercise

noun.description: A type or variety of something.
examples: sponsorship is a form of advertising

noun.description: The customary or correct method or procedure; what is usually done.
examples: an excessive concern for legal form and precedent

noun.description: A mold, frame, or block in or on which something is shaped.
A printed document with blank spaces for information to be inserted.
A class or year in a school, usually given a specifying number.
The state of an athlete or sports team with regard to their current standard of performance.
examples: they've been in good form this season

noun.description: A long bench without a back.

verb.description: Bring together parts or combine to create (something)
Make or fashion into a certain shape or form.

phrases: She went out in the second round of the women's doubles but hopes to be back on form for this month's Commonwealth Games.
When they are on form they look great but when they're not they look very average.
Gough said all of England's players needed to be in form by the start of the Test series in July.
He is very fast and skillful, and when on form he is the best player in the team.
France's Philippe Lima, with wins in Spain and his home county in the last two months, is clearly the man in form.
origin: Middle English: from Old French forme (noun), fo(u)rmer (verb, from Latin formare to form), both based on Latin forma a mold or form.
